ratings.comment: Alexandre means well. He is truly passionate about the subject & course and wants his students to succeed. However, his lectures are pointless at times and I learned most of the material from the textbook. Read the textbook and study HW & textbook questions for the exam!
Great professor, easy class to pass if you go to lectures

He is a great professor who truly cares about his students. He sprinkles some good life advice into his lectures. Many students seem to struggle with astro 104, but if you have taken a physics class and go to most lectures this class will be an easy A in my opinion.

The course is graded on 3 exams which often include questions from the homework, but there are some surprises on the exams. He does one "practice exam" at the beginning of the semester which isn't worth anything. His lectures were quite boring and it was often difficult to understand him. He did boost exam scores randomly, but don't count on that.

Alex Lazarian is a lot of things - a professor, an astronomer, highly intelligent, occasionally funny - but he is not a good lecturer. I do not believe I learned a single thing during lecture; I learned almost all of the course materials out of the textbook. I would not recommend unless you are willing and able to do most of the learning yourself

Professor Lazarian likes to hear himself talk more than teach, his exams are 90% of the grade with homework being worth only 10%. I once asked him & TA's for help and he said that asking for help is taking advantage of TA's. There are 2 lectures posted every week. They're almost an hour each. This class is not fun or worth it.

Communication/course page is not great. Lectures are minimally useful. Class is mostly self-taught from textbook. Homework questions and Exam questions often repeat themselves, so the tests aren't hard but are weighted heavily. Subject is interesting, but I don't feel like I'm mastering any material - you don't need to really learn much to get an A

He's an absolute mess. Canvas page is very unorganized, his lectures are y disengaging and hard to understand because of his lectures. Both he and the TA are very hands-off so expect to do a lot of self-teaching. The lectures aren't very helpful, don't waste your time, I would recommend just reading the textbook.

Online learning was a breeze mostly because all you had to do was watch about 30 minutes worth of videos for discussion each week, 10 min max of homework and lectures were videos that are easy speed up since he talks pretty slow. The only thing I didn't like was that there were no announcements for lectures being posted. Quizlet is your best friend

He has a heavy accent that takes a while to get used to, still, I could only understand probably 70% of the things he said. Lectures are just a bunch of slides that don't really cover everything on the tests, so get ready for quite a bit of textbook reading. All the tests are multiple choices so it's pretty hard to get good grades on them.

I personally skipped most lectures as I had a very difficult time understanding him. From what I've heard though, if you're able to go to all lectures and pay attention to him/understand him, the class will be a lot easier for you.

He has a strong accent which made it hard to understand him at first but you get used to it pretty quickly. Communication about the class was sub-par, he never said where the final exam was at and some people showed up to the wrong room. Lectures are super interesting and you learn a lot of cool stuff even if you aren't a science a major.

Attendance wasn't mandatory, but covered everything that was on exams. Gave make-up midterms and even curved them. Homework took 5-10 minutes once a week. Has an accent, but nothing you can't understand.

This was a great class for a non STEM student. Everything was straight forward and the tests are not bad at all, especially if you go to class because him and the TA cover the important stuff that makes it into the tests while the book covers a lot of extra stuff. Also, English isnt his first language, but hes still really funny. Great Class

Lectures are boring to me because he speaks with an accent so I find it a bit hard to understand what he's saying but he does know his stuff. 3 midterms (only 2 counted). I'd say it's pretty easy he normally just recycle the questions from past midterms so shouldn't be too hard. Lectured aren't compulsory to get an A. Missed few and still get an A.

10 minute homework once every week 3 exams+make up exam for 1st exam which is nice, easy questions that he recycles onto the exams. Show up to lecture and you will learn lots of interesting stuff and do well on exams and homework. Textbook never used. Class was interesting and little to no work load, yet learned lots of cool stuff!

I found his class to be very easy, but a large part of that was my interest in the topic. I do not think that missing a lecture or two would have cost my grade, but I still never missed. He cares about the topic, clearly. His only flaw is being sidetracked and becoming distracted by a tangent for a few minutes, but other than that, hes great.

It is obvious that this guy knows a lot of stuff about his profession. However, he has this really weird accent that makes it almost impossible to understand what he is talking about. P.S: His favorite phrase is "Interestingly Enough"

He's a really great lecturer that knows a lot about the subject and is obviously interested and passionate about what he is talking about which always gets me involved. All you have to do is the homework and attend lecture and you will do well. What he teaches is super interesting as well.

As a person, this man is obviously very intelligent about physics/astronomy/science/etc. He was also super funny, but it seemed like the class didn't pick up on his humor much. As a class, Astron104 was very disorganized, discussion sections were basically useless, and questions from practice exams/homework were copy and pasted to exams.

Tests are important but easy. You dont need the textbook to do well in the class. Study the homework, the some of the questions are on the test word for word. Going to lectures arent necessary either as long as the slides are posted online.

Best class I've taken. Professor is a genius Russian guy who's hilarious. One 20 question homework assignment a week with all the answers online. Three tests and all the questions are the ones from the homework. You don't need to go to the lectures but I did because Laz is hilarious. Also learned a lot about the Solar System

Lectures were basically review. You can get an A by just reading the book and going over the MC at the end of the chapter.  TA Sections completely worthless.  Homework was easy.  Easy A as long as you read the chapters and do some minor studying for the exams.

Alex is a smart guy, and you can tell when you're sitting in his class. However, he isn't the best professor; the class is pretty unorganized and topics unclear because he is all over the place with what he covers in lecture. TAs don't really know what's going on, and oftentimes there are questions on the tests that were not discussed in class.

His usually reads off of the slides the entire lecture and the slides are almost word for word out of the textbook. He has a very heavy accent. The discussions are completely pointless, they have little to nothing to do with doing well in the class. You could not go once and not have any problems. The tests are pretty easy, some confusing questions

Can't understand him at all.  Doesn't use a microphone so it's especially tough to understand him with his accent.  Awful at finishing sentences, don't know what he's saying.  Not a good professor at all

You can't understand Alex. He knows his stuff and clearly is passionate but you learn very little. Do not take the class if you're looking for an easy A because it most certainly is not. The TA's were atrocious and did not make the class any easier. Lectures are boring and showing up doesn't do you much good. Would not recommend.

He's very knowledgeable on the material, but tends to ramble on unnecessary points while flying through important slides. But he posts all the slides online, and lectures are easy as can be. Also sit close to the front because he doesn't use a microphone. If you do the work and understand reoccurring concepts, you won't have any problems.

It is very difficult to understand his accent but luckily you can just copy down the notes from the powerpoint. The class is deceiving. The material seems easy but then the tests test you on less important topics.

Lectures are pointless because he posts the slides of every one. 3 exams throughout the year that are all multiple choice so if you know the material enough you'll do well. Weekly homework assignments that can be very long if you leave them for the night before they are due. Didn't go to discussion ever.

Prof. Lazarian is clearly a genius and genuinely kind. His class however was a disaster. His accent and quiet speaking voice made lecture a struggle to understand. Your TA will become the primary teacher, so hope for a good one. Tests were tough, but not impossible. I regret taking it.

He has an accent but most students can get use to it. He missed a total of 3 weeks and many were during exams so it was difficult to ask him questions, especially because there did end up being mistakes. He is unclear about exam material and often puts things on that he said would not be on the exams. TAs will be your savior in this class.

The man is a genius, and he seems like a nice guy, but his lectures are confusing at best. He will ramble off on a tangent about something he finds interesting, only to skip key vocab on the slides. Exams are cumulative and pretty tough, but there are many repeated questions, so go to your TA's office hours to review midterms. Read the book!

Homework assignments every week, but they're usually pretty easy. Hope for a good TA, but the discussions aren't mandatory or very useful. The good TA is just for grading your homework. He is extremely hard to understand in lecture. You basically have to learn for yourself off his slides.

Lazarian has a very heavy accent and mumbles a lot to the point you won't understand him outside of the powerpoints. The tests are very specific and no matter how many times you go to office hours, he is of no help at all. You can tell he is a brilliant man, but he just has trouble conveying the material effectively.

Very difficult to understand, puts questions on the test that do not relate in any way to the material learned in class. Goes off on tangents that are irrelevant, yet speeds through slides so fast that you are not able to take notes on the important information. Is never present for exams, and is out of class about as much as he is in it. DONT TAKE

He is very hard to understand, and doesnt wear a microphone dispite lecturing in a large hall. Lots of "umms and uhhs" and mumbling. Seems like a nice guy but he isnt super clear and the tests are tricky to study for since there isnt much guidance.

Lectures are useless. Half the time he speaks so quietly you can't hear him and the other half  was incoherent due to his accent. Claimed that tests would only be on lecture material but then actually tested on random concepts that were not in lecture or the reading. Take this class if you enjoy being frustrated every time you go to lecture.
Hard to understand in lecture sometimes, and often goes on tangents. Exams are tough, with a not clearly emphasized curve on each. Still, not to terrible of a class.

He's obviously a very intelligent man, but he's very unclear about what to study for on the tests and even sometimes difficult to understand. Make sure you have a good TA, or you're screwed. Super unhelpful.

You can tell he's an absolutely brilliant man, but for a 103 class he makes it too hard. He's difficult to understand and mumbles a lot. The homework and practice questions are SO much easier than his actual tests, so they're not much help in preparing. I'm an AB student, studied my butt off for the first exam, and got a D. Good luck...

Interesting material. Sometimes difficult to understand Lazarian in lecture, so your grade is highly dependent on your TA's ability to convey the material. I had Min-Young and she was very helpful. Tests repeat a TON of questions, so if you go to your TA's office hours and take notes on the older tests, you're golden

He'll mumble a lot, you can tell he knows a lot but can convey only an eighth of that knowledge with us because of his limited English vocabulary. Tests are so detailed it's difficult to pinpoint exactly what to study. My TA was good and I understood the content but he was boring and the tests were long and detailed.

Lazarian's lectures are always interesting and are usually easy to follow. Discussions have little to no relevance to what you need to know for the exams. Study off the lecture slides and go to class.
The class isn't too bad. All the lecture notes go online but pay attention to details he adds in during class.
Clearly passionate about what he teaches.  Extremely receptive to the classes needs.  Very well spoken and a great teacher.

I can barely understand him because of his mysterious accent. Sometimes he will just start umming and ahhhing for like 5 min and I zone out completely. He really makes astronomy boring. The Tests are alright but accumulative every time, so you have to review for every test. The homerok used to suck but now he made it alot easier.

His accent takes time to get used to, however - he puts all the slides online, which is nice. He says you don't need the textbook for anything other than homework, but it really helps to read the chapters before the tests.
Sometimes hard to understand, but the class is a piece of cake, thank god for a good TA!
Honestly, I spend lecture time on my computer (actually, I'm in lecture for this class right now!).  It's a pointless class, but if you want an easy grade point boost it will do.

There's no doubt that he is into what he's teaching, but much of the time he fails to get the point he is trying to make across. He gets easily flustered  when things go wrong. Pretty easy tests, multiple choice.

Alex was a pretty funny guy when he decided to make jokes, although he was hard to understand a lot of the time. Discussion was spent trying to decipher what he'd talked about in class. It helped a ton to make vocab sheets/study guides for the exams (which were not that bad, just 25 multiple choice Qs). Your TA will make or break the class for you!
